sect1.title: What is BeanDoc (and why would I care?)
sect1.para: Spring BeanDoc is a tool for documenting context definition files used in Spring projects. An unmodified beandoc run produces HTML with a JavaDoc-ish look and feel to it, and graphs of the context showing dependencies, inheritance and other common constructs. However, the tool is highly configurable and extensible to meet most needs.

caption.para: Sample output showing a JPetStore page

sect1.para: The tool documents a multi-file application context in a repeatable, fast way and is runnable from standard development tools such as IDE's, Ant or command shells. Re-using a standard set of properties tailored to your needs with different projects or context files is a trivial operation.

BeanDoc integrates with other open source tools where appropriate. Significant among them is the graphing package for generating the image graphs, and this will need to be downloaded and installed separately on your machine. Fortunately this is an extremely simple operation.

sect2.title: CVS
sect2.para: Spring BeanDoc is part of the SpringFramework CVS repository, existing as a separate module from the main Spring sources. You can view the module via Fisheye or check it out anonymously using CVS. Shown below are the commands required from the CVS command-line, see your preferred tool's documentation if you wish to use that instead.
SourceForge has more information on anonymous CVS access for the springframework project.

sect2.title: Releases
sect2.para: If you don't wish to track CVS you can download release files which contain all of the project sources, samples and compiled documentation instead.

sect2.title: Building the sources
sect2.para: Having checked out or unzipped the project sources, cd to the root of the project directory and invoke ant dist to generate the spring-beandoc.jar file. This file, along with all other runtime dependencies will be placed in target/dist (unless you overrode the target directory in your local build.properties). Runtime libs can now be added to any of your Spring projects that you wish to document, or just left where they are and referenced on the classpath.

sect1.title: GraphViz
sect1.para: One of the most useful features of BeanDoc is its ability to generate configurable graphs of the context files. The actual graphing tool used is called GraphViz, and you will need to obtain and install a copy for your platform from their website. Thanks to the ATT guys for a great tool.
